The troops and officers, whom Attalus had sent into that province, were defeated and ssain3 and the active zeal of Heraclian maintained his own allegiance, and that of his people. The faithful count of Africa transmitted a large sum of money, which fixed‘ the attachment of the Imperial guards3 and his vigilance, in preventing the exportation of corn and oil, introduced famine, tumult, and discontent, into the walls of Rome. The failure of the African expedition, was the source of mutual complaint and recrimination in the party of Attalus; and the mind of his protector was insenfibly alienated from the interest of a prince, who wanted spirit to command, or docility to obey.. The most imprudent measures were adopted, without the knowledge, or against the advice, of Alaric; and the obstinate refusal of the senate, to allow, in the embarkation, the mixture even of five hun- dred Goths, betrayed a suspicions and distrustful temper, which, in their fituation, was neither generous nor prudent.
